etymologies: mid 17th century (as a verb): probably from Dutch kruisen ‘to cross’, from kruis ‘cross’, from Latin crux

definitions: sail about in an area without a precise destination, especially for pleasure

examples.text: they were cruising off the California coast
she cruised the canals of France in a barge

definitions: take a vacation on a ship or boat following a predetermined course, usually calling in at several ports.
(of a vehicle or person) travel or move slowly around without a specific destination in mind

examples.text: a police van cruised past us
teenagers were aimlessly cruising the mall

shortDefinitions: move slowly around with no specific destination

definitions: wander about a place in search of a casual sexual partner

examples.text: he spends his time cruising and just hanging out in New Orleans
he cruised the gay bars of Los Angeles

shortDefinitions: wander about in search of sexual partner

definitions: walk past and assess (a potential sexual partner)

examples.text: he was cruising a pair of sailors

shortDefinitions: walk past and assess potential sexual partner

definitions: (of a motor vehicle or aircraft) travel smoothly at a moderate or economical speed

examples.text: we sit in a jet, cruising at some 30,000 ft

definitions: achieve an objective with ease, especially in sports

examples.text: he cruised to an easy victory in Tuesday's primary

definitions: (of a young child) walk while holding on to furniture or other structures, prior to learning to walk without support

examples.text: my daughter cruised at seven months and didn't walk until just after her first birthday
about a week ago she started crawling forwards, cruising furniture, and standing by herself

shortDefinitions: (of young child) walk while holding on to furniture etc.

definitions: a voyage on a ship or boat taken for pleasure or as a vacation and usually calling in at several places
